content.description: Begin at the Practice Chimney and climb down and right below an overhanging bulge.  Continue right just above the ground until you reach the grungy section at the Weeping Wall.

There are numerous variations, from about 5.9 to 5.11a, depending on where on the face you decide to climb. 

  Climb an overhnag to a small ledge, then up the center of the face to another small overhang.  Reach over the hang to find good holds, then step right and up and climb the right side of a short face to the top.  The outside corner to the right is off if you want the full 5.10b grade.
content.protection: TR, or 3 bolts on face (new in 2011). There is a 2 bolt anchor at the top, however they are not rap hangers.
content.location: On the narrow face just left (north) of the Weeping Wall.  You can reach the top of the cliff from the top of the Practice Face with some 4th class scrambling.

content.description: Climb the leftmost seam, then straight up through the overhangs to the top.  Perhaps a bit harder than the rating.  Climbing the center seam (var. 1) makes the climb 5.8 and climbing the face between the right most seam and the next crack to the right (Ivy Leaf) makes the climb 5.9 (var 2).
content.protection: Standard rack. Double bolt anchor with chains at the top.
content.location: Begin at the far left edge of the Practice Face below three short parallel seams that diagonal up and left (variations climb the different seams).

content.description: Climb the obvious wide, broken crack to the top.
content.location: At a prominent wide crack at the right (east) end of the Practice Face.

content.description: Climb the obvious damp, dark chimney to the top.
content.location: At the obvious chimney on the far right (east) side of the Practice Face.

content.description: Pull the overhang onto an awkward, sloping ledge.
content.location: Under the lower overhanging bulge beneath Shit Face.

content.description:
Climb the crack in the center of the Practice Face to its end.  Move up and left past a notch to a small ledge, then up to the top.  A variation (also 5.4) moves up and right from the end of the crack to the top. 

  A Variation of this climb follows the main crack until it ends before the overhangs, then follows another crack up to the right. Ivy Leaf shares a double bolted chain anchor with "Triple Overhang" (route to the left of Ivy Leaf). However, there is a different double bolted chain anchor for the variation.
content.location: At the base of an obvious crack about 10 feet right of the left edge of the Practice Face.

content.description: Climb the smooth face between the cracks of Ivy Leaf (20 feet left) and Practice Climb (8 feet right) past a short crack and left-facing corner.  Continue more or less straight up through the small overhangs/bulges to the top.
content.location: On the right side of the Practice Face, just left of the prominent wide crack (Practice Climb).

content.description: Reach up for the jug and climb the arete for 5 feet to a stance.  Escape left.  Use only the overhanging arete for feet.
content.location: At a plate-like jug where the Practice Chimney forms an overhanging arete.

content.description:
The Practice Face is the most popular area at High Rocks due to easy routes and easy access for top ropes.  This face is often a mob scene on busy weekends; however, the climbs are quite nice and worth getting up early to beat the crowds. 

  Please do not use the eroded gully on the north side of the practice face for top rope access.   Scramble a bit further north (toward the parking lot) by a tree and use the obvious ledge system. 

  The routes around the left hand corner of the Practice Face, Orvie Direct and The End Climb (aka Orvie), are described on the a. Descent Trail Area page.
